sen.j: 藤原 隆房（ふじわら の たかふさ、久安4年(1148年) - 承元3年(1209年)）は平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期にかけての公卿。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Takafusa (1148 - 1209) was a Kugyo (high-ranking court official) who lived from the end of Heian period to the early Kamakura period.
FUJIWARA no Takafusa (1148 - 1209) was a Kugyo (high-ranking court official) who lived from the end of the Heian period to the early years of the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: Heian period to the early Kamakura period → the Heian period to the early years of the Kamakura period
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Takafusa (1148 - 1209) was a kugyo (high-ranking court official) who lived from the end of the Heian period to the early years of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 藤原北家善勝寺流の出身で権大納言藤原隆季の長男。
sen.e: He was from the Zensho-ji line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and the eldest son of FUJUWARA no Takasue who served as Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor).
He was a descendent of the Zensho-ji line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and the eldest son of FUJUWARA no Takasue, who served as Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor).
sen.cmt: This is a minor point as the checker should be able to correct this easily, but as "who served as Gon dainagon " is non-defining, a comma should be used.
sen.e: He was a descendent of the Zenshoji line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and the eldest son of FUJIWARA no Takasue, Gon Dainagon (a provisional chief councilor of state).
sen.cmt: 用語集より補足しました。

sen.j: 母は大蔵卿藤原忠隆の娘。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of FUJUWARA no Tadataka who served as Okurakyo (head of the Ministry of Finance)
His mother was a daughter of FUJUWARA no Tadataka, who served as Okurakyo (head of the Ministry of Finance)
sen.cmt: "who served as Okurakyo" is also non-defining.
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of FUJIWARA no Tadataka, who served as Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).
sen.cmt: 用語集より補足しました。

sen.e: He rose to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and served as Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor).
He rose to the rank of Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and served as Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor).
sen.cmt: I realize a translation of "Shonii" is provided but adding "the rank of" makes this a little easier for the reader, I think.
sen.e: He rose to the rank of Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and served as Gon Dainagon.
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 四条隆房、冷泉隆房とも。
sen.e: He was also called as Takafusa SHIJO or Takafusa REIZEI.

sen.e: His children were Takahira SHIJO and Ryuben.

sen.j: 保元3年(1158年)に従五位下に叙爵。
sen.e: In 1158 he was conferred a peerage, Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: 以後加賀国、因幡国の国司や左右の中将、蔵人頭などを歴任し、元暦元年(1184年)に従三位に叙せられる。
sen.e: Afterward, he experienced various posts such as Kokushi (officer of local government) of Kaga Province and of Inaba Province, Sayu no chujo (middle captains of the left and right palace guards), and Kurodo no to (chief of the palace office), and was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1184.
sen.cmt: he was investitured Jusanmiでいいのですが、ここでは前文に従五位下が出ていますので、was promoted to Jusanmiの方が自然であるとしました。
sen.e: Afterward, he experienced various posts such as Kokushi (officer of local government) of Kaga Province and of Inaba Province, Sayu no chujo (middle captains of the left and right palace guards), and Kurodo no to (chief of the palace office), and was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1184.

Afterward, he experienced various posts such as kokushi (provincial governors) of Kaga Province and Inaba Province, Sayu no chujo (middle captains of the left and right palace guards), and Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1184.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 文治5年(1189年)に権中納言、正治元年(1199年)に中納言、正二位、元久元年(1204年)には権大納言に至る。
sen.e: In 1189 he was appointed as Gon chunagon (provisional middle councilor), and was promoted to Chunagon (middle councilor), Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1199, and reached Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor) in 1204.

In 1189 he was appointed as Gon chunagon (provisional middle councilor), and was promoted to Chunagon (middle councilor), Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1199, and reached Gon dainagon (provisional major councilor) in 1204.

In 1189 he was appointed as Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state), and was promoted to Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1199, and reached Gon Dainagon in 1204.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 建永元年(1206年)に出家し引退（戒名は寂恵）。
sen.e: In 1206 he retired and became a priest; in 1209 he died, his Kaimyo (posthumous Buddhist name), Jakue.
sen.cmt: 原文に 「1209年に死去」はありませんが、戒名を法名と混乱しそうなので、あえて追加しました。
sen.e: In 1206 he retired and became a priest; in 1209 he died, his Kaimyo (posthumous Buddhist name), Jakue.
In 1206 he retired and became a priest (his Buddhist name, Jakue).
sen.cmt: 「戒名」は、「出家・在家に与えられた法名(Yahoo辞書）」の意味もあり、またウェブでは「法名」となっていたため、訳文を修正しました。

sen.j: 平清盛の娘を正室とした関係から平家一門と親しく、平家没落の後にも建礼門院を庇護したとされる。
sen.e: Because his legal wife was a daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was close to the Taira clan, and was said to patronize Kenreimon-in even after the decline of the Taira clan.
sen.cmt: 平家没落→the declining of the Taira family →the decline of the Taira clan[同一文中にclanと familyが使い分けされているのは不自然なため、ここでは統一しました]
sen.e: Because his legal wife was a daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was close to the Taira clan, and was said to patronize Kenreimon-in even after the decline of the Taira clan.
Because his legal wife was a daughter of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was close to the Taira clan, and was said to patronize Kenreimonin even after the decline of the Taira clan.

sen.j: その一方で後白河法皇の寵臣としても名高く、平家の衰退と関わりなく政治上の発言権を保ち続けた。
sen.e: On the other hand, he was famous as a favorite retainer of the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa in the Priesthood, and maintained strong political influence in spite of the downfall of the Taira family.
sen.cmt: 後白河法皇→Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa→the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa in the Priesthood[用語統一リストのCloistered Emperorでは上皇（Retired Emperor)の意が匂わず、またcloisterは修道院で、隠遁するに近い意味合いもありますので、政治的権力を保った上皇とは少し違うのではないかと思い、他に適当な訳は見つけられませんでしたが、「仏門に入った」という意味のin the priesthood をつけてみました。]
sen.e: On the other hand, he was famous as a favorite retainer of the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa in the Priesthood, and maintained strong political influence in spite of the downfall of the Taira family.
On the other hand, he was famous as a favorite retainer of the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, and maintained strong political influence in spite of the downfall of the Taira family.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 政界遊泳に長けていたばかりでなく、歌人としても存在感を発揮し、『千載集』に入選している他、近年では『朗詠百首』の作者にも擬せられている。
sen.e: He not only knew very well how to survive in the political world but was also recognized as an excellent Kajin poet; his poem was selected for "Senzaishu," and recently he is mentioned as a possible writer of "Roei hyakushu."

He not only knew very well how to survive in the political world but was also recognized as an excellent Kajin poet; his poems were selected for "Senzaishu," and recently he is mentioned as a possible writer of "Roei hyakushu."

He not only knew very well how to survive in the political world but was also recognized as an excellent poet; his poems were selected for "Senzaishu" (Collection of a Thousand Years) and recently he is mentioned as a possible writer of "Roei hyakushu" (literally, one hundred of poems for recitation).

sen.j: 日記としては『安元御賀日記』を書き遺しており、また『平家物語』における小督との恋愛譚もよく知られている。
sen.e: His diary was called "Angen onga nikki," and his love story with Kogo in "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of Taira family) was well known.
sen.cmt: 「も」,tooをつけると英語として不自然なようで省きました。
sen.e: His diary was called "Angen onga nikki," and his love story with Kogo in "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of Taira family) was well known.

His diary was called "Angen onga no nikki" (the record of the ceremony celebrating Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa's 50th birthday) and his love story with Kogo in "Heike monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike) was well known.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 子孫は羽林家の一つ四条家として繁栄し、現代に至るまで続いている。
sen.e: His offspring prospered as one of the Urin families, the Shijo family, which exists even now.
